text: The reason for its disappearance is not known, but it was probably the result of multiple factors, not the least of which was human intervention.
It is now thought that the rapid spread of plague during the Middle Ages was the result of person-to-person transmission through respiratory aerosols.

Beginning in the late seventeenth century, governments created a medical boundary, or cordon sanitaire, between Europe and the areas to the east from which epidemics came.

Although it wasn’t until the nineteenth century that doctors understood how germs could cause disease, Europeans recognized by the sixteenth century that plague was contagious and could be carried from one area to another.
